intro: Gilia ochroleuca subsp. minima, commonly known as the smallflower gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and typically grows in dry, rocky habitats. The plant produces showy, bright yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, and it is often found in open grasslands and along streambanks. The subspecies is distinguished by its smaller flowers and shorter stems compared to other members of the species.
